content: Michel Armand (born 1946) is a French scientist known for introducing the rocking-chair battery concept in 1978. This type of battery involves de/intercalating the same type of ion into both positive and negative electrodes, minimizing solvent use and reducing battery weight and cost. Armand's interest in electrochemistry and batteries began at Ecole Normale Superieure in 1968. While at Stanford University as a Fulbright Scholar, he pursued practical battery development but returned to France to finish his PhD due to a focus on fundamental studies. His work in graduate school led to a patent on using solid polymer electrolytes to intercalate lithium and potassium ions into graphite. Without his contributions, lithium batteries as power sources for electronic devices would not be as advanced as they are today. Armand currently leads a research team in Spain and has been published in Nature.

Raised in the American Midwest, he worked as a telegraph operator early in his career, which inspired some of his earliest inventions. content:
Stanford Robert Ovshinsky (November 24, 1922 – October 17, 2012) was an American engineer, scientist, and inventor who was granted over 400 patents in the areas of energy and information. His inventions, such as the nickel-metal hydride battery and thin-film solar energy laminates, have had wide-ranging applications in electronics and renewable energy industries.

Ovshinsky's research in the 1940s and 50s opened the scientific field of amorphous and disordered materials, leading to the development of technologies based on amorphous silicon semiconductors. He was self-taught, without formal college or graduate training, and his love for science and social convictions drove his inventive work.

In 1960, Ovshinsky and his wife, Iris Dibner, founded the Energy Conversion Laboratory, which later became Energy Conversion Devices (ECD). ECD became a leading invention and development laboratory, creating technologies aimed at making fossil fuels obsolete. After Iris Ovshinsky's death in 2006, Ovshinsky established Ovshinsky Innovation LLC to develop new energy and information technologies. He married Rosa Young, a physicist who

content:
美国发明家内森·贝弗利·斯塔布菲尔德（Nathan Beverly Stubblefield）（1860年11月22日至1928年3月28日）以他的无线电话工作而闻名。他自称是一名“实用的农民，果园主和电工”，在1902年初，他举行了一系列公开演示，展示了一种使用电池操作的无线电话，可以被运输到不同的位置并在移动平台上使用，如船只。尽管这种初始设计使用传导，但1908年，他获得了一项使用磁感应的无线电话系统的美国专利。然而，他最终未能将他的发明商业化。他后来隐居起来，并于1928年独自去世。

关于斯塔布菲尔德的通讯技术是否可以被分类为无线电以及他在1902年的演示是否可以被认为是第一个“广播”，存在争议。大多数对他的努力的评价认为它们不是无线电传输，因为他的设备，尽管使用了一种“无线”形式，但使用了传导和感应场，而无线电的标准定义是电磁辐射的传输。但是，斯塔布菲尔德可能是第一个同时向多个接收器无线传输音频的人，尽管距离相对较短，同时预测了国家范围内广播的最终发展。

content: Alessandro Volta, an Italian physicist and chemist, is known for inventing the electric battery and discovering methane. In 1799, he created the voltaic pile, proving that electricity could be generated chemically and debunking the prevailing theory that it was only produced by living beings. His invention sparked scientific interest and led to the development of electrochemistry. Volta was admired by Napoleon Bonaparte, who invited him to demonstrate his invention at the Institute of France. He held the chair of experimental physics at the University of Pavia for nearly 40 years and was close to the emperor. Despite his professional success, Volta preferred a domestic life, especially in his later years. He died in 1827, and the SI unit of electric potential is named the volt in his honor.

content: An alkaline battery (IEC code: L) uses potassium hydroxide as an electrolyte, which gives it a pH value above 7. It generates energy from the reaction between zinc and manganese dioxide. Compared to zinc–carbon batteries, alkaline batteries have higher energy density, longer shelf life, and the same voltage. They use potassium hydroxide instead of acidic electrolytes like ammonium chloride or zinc chloride. Alkaline batteries make up 80% of manufactured batteries in the US and over 10 billion units are produced worldwide. They are used in household items such as portable media players, digital cameras, toys, flashlights, and radios.

content: A 4D vector is a 4-component data type in computer science, commonly used for homogeneous coordinates in 3D computer graphics and RGBA values in bitmap images. It can also represent quaternions for

An emulator is hardware or software that allows one computer system (the host) to imitate another computer system (the guest). This enables the host to run software or use peripheral devices designed for the guest. For example, many printers are designed to emulate HP LaserJet printers to run software written for HP printers. Emulators are also used by video game enthusiasts to play classic arcade games and old video game consoles. A hardware emulator takes the form of a hardware device, such as a DOS-compatible card installed in some 1990s-era Macintosh computers. The Church-Turing thesis implies that any operating environment can be emulated within any other environment, but it can be difficult, particularly if the exact behavior of the system to be emulated is not documented. Timing constraints can also affect the performance of the emulation.

Flat-panel displays (FPD) are electronic displays used for visual content in various industries. They are thin, lightweight, and offer higher resolution than previous TVs. In the 2010s, they replaced CRT displays and are widely used in consumer electronics like laptops and smartphones. Most use LCD or LED technology, with touch screen capabilities. There are two types: volatile, which requires electronic refresh for image retention, and static, which retains content even without power.

content: Hardware security, originating from cryptographic engineering, involves hardware design, access control, secure multi-party computation, secure key storage, and ensuring code authenticity. A hardware security module (HSM) safeguards and manages digital keys for strong authentication. Providers in this discipline emphasize the use of "non-Turing-machine" logic, such as raw combinatorial logic or simple state machines. Hardware backdoors and hardware Trojans are malicious modifications in electronic systems and integrated circuits, respectively. Physical unclonable functions (PUFs) are physical entities embodied in a structure that is easy to evaluate but hard to predict, making them difficult to duplicate. PUFs are typically implemented in integrated circuits for applications with high security requirements. Many attacks on sensitive data and resources occur from within organizations themselves.

content: A Hardware Trojan (HT) is a malicious modification of the circuitry of an integrated circuit, characterized by its physical representation and behavior. The payload of an HT is the activity it executes when triggered, such as leaking confidential information or disabling components. HTs can be introduced during chip design, purchased from non-reputable sources, or inserted internally by a rogue employee. It has been demonstrated that a hardware design containing a Trojan could leak a cryptographic key over an antenna or network connection when triggered. In high security governmental IT departments, hardware Trojans are a known problem when purchasing equipment from non-reputable sources, as they could leak passwords or provide unauthorized entry.

Hardware-based encryption involves using computer hardware to assist or replace software in the process of data encryption, often as part of the processor's instruction set. For example, the AES encryption algorithm can be implemented using specific instruction sets on architectures such as x86 and ARM. In some systems, the cryptography module is separate from the central processor and implemented as a separate coprocessor, such as the I

content: A vintage computer, considered largely obsolete, has sparked a sub-culture of collectors who are willing to spend large sums to acquire and restore these items to their fully functioning glory. This includes homebrew developers and hackers who update and create hybrid composites from old computers for modern uses. Some vintage 8-bit machines have even been designed with modern interfaces for limited Internet connectivity. The Vintage Computer Festival, held annually since 1997, celebrates and showcases vintage computers and has expanded internationally.

content: Home computers were a type of microcomputer that was available from 1977 to 1995. They were designed for the average consumer and were more affordable than business computers. These computers featured a keyboard, a display, the ability to run games and applications, and a removable mass storage device. This list excludes smartphones, PDAs, pocket computers, laptops, calculators, and video game consoles. Hobby microcomputers and school computers are listed separately as they required different skills and had different features. Today, the price of microcomputers has dropped, making separate, incompatible series for home users unnecessary.

content: This is a list of home computers, sorted alphanumerically, with details on their video hardware. Home computers, second-generation desktop computers, were common in the 1980s and were replaced by IBM PC compatible "PCs" in the 1990s. Early examples include the TRS-80, Atari 8-bit computers, BBC Micro, ZX Spectrum, MSX, Amstrad CPC 464, and Commodore 64. Later examples include MSX 2, Amiga, and Atari ST systems. Only home computers from manufacturers are listed, not personal computers, which are based on the VGA standard. PCs could only compete with home computers after the introduction of the VGA standard. Gaming systems like the Atari 2600 and Bally Astrocade, which could be upgraded to resemble a home computer, are not listed.

content: Asynchronous circuits, also known as clockless or self-timed circuits, are sequential digital logic circuits that do not rely on a global clock signal to synchronize their components. Instead, they use handshaking circuits to indicate the completion of instructions, and simple data transfer protocols. Although most digital devices today use synchronous circuits, asynchronous circuits have the potential to be faster, consume less power, have lower electromagnetic interference, and offer better modularity in large systems. They are an active area of research in digital logic design and were shown to be commercially viable in the 1990s

content: Clock gating is a popular power management technique in computer architecture that helps reduce dynamic power dissipation in synchronous circuits. It works by removing the clock signal when the circuit or a part of it is not in use, saving power by pruning the clock tree. This means that portions of the circuitry are disabled, preventing flip-flops from switching state and consuming power. A clock generator is an electronic oscillator that produces a clock signal for synchronizing circuit operation. It can range from a simple square wave to more complex arrangements. All clock generators share a resonant circuit and an amplifier. The resonant circuit is usually a quartz piezo-electric oscillator or simpler tank or RC circuits. The amplifier circuit inverts the signal and feeds a portion back to maintain oscillation.

content: Clock skew is the variation in the arrival time of the same clock signal at different components in a digital circuit, caused by gate or wire signal propagation delay. The difference in readings of two clocks is called their skew. Digital circuits are synchronized by a periodic signal known as a "clock" that dictates the sequence and pacing of devices. Ideally, the input to each memory element reaches its final value in time for the next clock tick. The maximum speed at which a system can run must account for variance due to differences in physical composition, temperature, and path length. In a synchronous circuit, two registers are said to be "sequentially adjacent" if a logic path connects them, and clock skew is defined as the difference in clock arrival times at the source and destination register clock pins.

AMD Cool'n'Quiet is a power-saving technology that reduces a processor's clock rate and voltage when idle, aiming to lower power consumption and heat generation for quieter fan operation. It is similar to Intel's SpeedStep and AMD's PowerNow! technologies. Cool'n'Quiet is used for desktop and server chips, while PowerNow! is for mobile chips. It is fully supported in the Linux kernel from version 2.6.18 onward and in FreeBSD from 6.0-CURRENT onward.

Clock multipliers determine the ratio of the internal CPU clock rate to the externally supplied clock, often set using PLL frequency multiplier circuitry. For example, a 36x clock multiplier with an external clock of 100 MHz results in an internal CPU clock of 3.6 GHz. The external address and data buses of the CPU also use the external clock as a timing base, but may use a multiple of this frequency for faster data transfer.

The internal frequency of microprocessors is usually based on the front side bus (FSB) frequency, calculated by multiplying the bus frequency by the clock multiplier. While some processors have fixed clock multipliers, others are unlocked and can be overclocked by increasing the multiplier setting in the motherboard's BIOS setup program. Additionally, some engineering samples may have unlocked multipliers. However, most production microprocessors cannot be overclocked using the clock multiplier and instead can be overclocked by increasing the FSB frequency.

content: The megahertz or gigahertz myth is the misconception that only clock rate can be used to compare the performance of microprocessors. Other factors such as execution units, cache hierarchy, and instruction sets also impact performance. Comparing different types of processors is difficult, as performance varies depending on the task. Benchmarks are a more thorough way of measuring and comparing computer performance. The myth started in 1984, when the IBM PC was claimed to be five times faster than the Apple II due to its higher clock speed. However, it's not just about clock speed, but how long it takes to complete a given task. For example, the LDA instruction takes 2 μs on the Apple II, but only 0.84 μs on the IBM PC, meaning the instruction runs only a little over 2 times faster on the IBM PC.

content: A memory divider is a ratio used to determine the operating clock frequency of computer memory in line with the front side bus (FSB) frequency. Memory dividers, along with latency timings, are heavily utilized in overclocking memory subsystems to achieve stable, working memory states at higher FSB frequencies. This ratio, known as the "DRAM:FSB ratio," is only applicable to chipsets where memory speed depends on FSB speeds. Chipsets like the nVidia 680i, which have separat

Overclocking, in computing, involves increasing a computer's clock rate beyond the manufacturer's specifications, usually requiring a higher operating voltage as well. This can lead to increased power consumption and heat, potentially causing instability or device failure if not managed properly. Overclocking typically voids warranties, but some manufactur

AMD PowerTune is a dynamic frequency scaling technology in AMD GPUs and APUs that allows the processor clock speed to be changed by software to meet performance needs while minimizing power draw, heat, and noise. It aims to solve power and performance constraints, reducing energy consumption and noise in desktop computers and extending battery life in mobile devices. It is the successor to AMD PowerPlay and was added to the Linux kernel driver "amdgpu" in 2015. AMD's x86-64 SMU firmware is executed o

Source-Synchronous clocking is a technique used to time symbols on a digital interface by having the transmitting device send a clock signal along with the data signals. This technique references the timing of unidirectional data signals to the clock sourced by the same device, rather than a global clock. content: Static core in integrated circuit design refers to a microprocessor (MPU) entirely implemented in static logic, allowing it to be halted by stopping the system clock while maintaining its state and resume processing when the clock signal is restarted. This type of MPU consumes very little power when the clock is stopped, making it useful for designs where the MPU remains in standby mode until needed and minimal power usage is desired. In comparison, typical microprocessors without a static core only refresh and present valid outputs during specific periods of the clock cycle, requiring them to run within a set range of clock frequencies to avoid issues caused by clock slowdown or stopping. Static core microprocessors include the RCA 1802, Intel 80386EX, WDC W65C02S, WDC W65C816S, and Freescale 683XX fami
see_also: Dynamic logic (digital logic)#Static versus dynamic logic

content: A synchronous circuit in digital electronics uses a clock signal to synchronize the changes in memory elements. Data is stored in flip-flops or latches, and the output remains constant until a pulse is applied to the "clock" input. A clock signal, generated by an electronic oscillator, is applied to every storage element, ensuring simultaneous changes in logical levels. However, some delay is required for each operation, limiting the maximum speed at which the system can run. Careful design of the clock distribution networks is essential for correct operation, often determined using static timing analysis. Nearly all digital circuits, including CPUs, are fully synchronous with a global clock, although there are exceptions such as self-synchronous circuits, globally

Founded in 1969, AMD initially focused on memory chips and components before entering the microprocessor market in 1975, competing with Intel. In the early 2000s, it experienced significant growth with its Athlon and Opteron processors, but faced challenges in the late 2000s and early 2010s. However, AMD regained market share in the late 2010s with its Ryzen processors, which were more competitive with Intel's in terms of performance in business applications.

Apple Inc., formerly Apple Computer, Inc., is a multinational corporation based in Cupertino, California, in Silicon Valley. It designs, develops, and sells consumer electronics, computer software, and online services, including the iPhone, iPad, Mac, Apple Watch, Vision Pro, and Apple TV, as well as iOS, iPadOS, and macOS operating systems, and software applications like iTunes, iCloud, Apple Music, and Apple TV+.

In 2022, Apple was the largest technology company by revenue and the largest vendor of mobile phones worldwide. It is one of the Big Five American information technology companies. Apple was founded in 1976 by Steve Wozniak and Steve Jobs to produce and market the Apple I personal computer. After a period of internal problems, including the departure of Jobs and Wozniak, the company faced bankruptcy in 1997. It turned around with the return of Jobs, introducing a series of successful products and campaigns. Apple has been criticized for its business practices but has maintained high brand loyalty and value, becoming the first publicly traded U.S. company to be valued at over $3 trillion in January 2022.

An application-specific integrated circuit (ASIC) is a customized IC chip designed for a specific use, such as in a digital voice recorder or video codec. These chips are typically fabricated using metal-oxide-semiconductor (MOS) technology and have grown in complexity from 5,000 logic gates to over 100 million gates over the years, often including microprocessors, memory blocks, and other building blocks, making them a system-on-chip (SoC). Designers use hardware description languages like Verilog or VHDL to describe their functionality.

On the other hand, field-programmable gate arrays (FPGA) are not application-specific and can be used in many different applications due to their programmable logic blocks and interconnects. For smaller designs or lower production volumes, FPGAs may be more cost-effective than ASICs, which can have non-recurring engineering (NRE) costs running into the m

A blitter is a circuit dedicated to quickly moving and modifying data in a computer's memory, often acting in parallel with the CPU. It can swiftly copy large amounts of data and is commonly used for moving bitmaps in graphical user interfaces or 2D games. The term "blit" comes from the bit-block transfer operation of the 1973 Xerox Alto. Blitters have been largely replaced by programmable graphics processing units.

C to HDL tools convert C code into hardware description languages like VHDL or Verilog, allowing synthesis into hardware devices like field-programmable gate arrays. Hardware designs consume less power, run faster, and offer more parallelism and throughput than software. However, designing and verifying in HDL can be time-consuming, leading engineers to write critical modules in HDL and use high-level synthesis for other modules. This method

content:
A custom hardware attack in cryptography uses application-specific integrated circuits (ASIC) to decrypt encrypted messages. Cryptographic brute force attacks require a large number of computations, which can be performed at a rate of millions per second on computers. However, the number of computations grows exponentially with the size of the key, and standard computers may not be fast enough. Cryptographic algorithms can be implemented in hardware, such as networks of logic circuits, which can execute algorithms hundreds of times faster than general-purpose computers.

ICs can be mass produced and mounted on printed circuit boards, with thousands or even millions of ICs applied to a single problem. Wafer-scale integration is also possible. content: Dataflow architecture is a contrast to traditional von Neumann or control flow architecture, with no program counter. The execution is based on the availability of input arguments, making the order of instruction execution unpredictable. While not used in general-purpose computer hardware, it has been successful in specialized hardware such as digital signal processing and network routing, as well as in data warehousing and artificial intelligence. Synchronous dataflow architectures are used in real-time data path applications, while deterministic dataflow architectures enable complex task management for programmers. However, there is a clash of terminology as the term dataflow is also used for a subarea of parallel progra

A digital signal processor (DSP) is a microprocessor chip optimized for digital signal processing needs, commonly used in audio processing, telecommunications, image processing, radar, and consumer electronic devices. DSPs are fabricated on integrated circuit chips and are known for their power efficiency, making them suitable for portable devices like mobile phones. Their specialized architecture allows them to measure, filter, or compress continuous analog signals, and they often utilize special memory architectures for faster data retrieval.

content: Direct memory access (DMA) is a computer system feature that allows hardware subsystems to access main system memory independently of the CPU. Without DMA, the CPU is fully occupied during read/write operations, but with DMA, the CPU can initiate the transfer, perform other operations, and receive an interrupt when the transfer is complete. This is useful when the CPU cannot keep up with data transfer rates or needs to work while waiting for slow I/O transfers. Many hardware systems use DMA, including disk drive controllers, graphics cards, network cards, and sound cards. It is also used for intra-chip data transfer in some multi-core processors. DMA allows for data transfer with less CPU overhead and can also be used for "memory to memory" copying or moving of data within memory. DMA offloads expensive memory operations fro

A FPGA is a type of configurable integrated circuit that can be repeatedly programmed after manufacturing. It is a subset of logic devices referred to as programmable logic devices and consists of an array of programmable logic blocks with a connecting grid. FPGAs are often used in limited quantity production of custom-made products and in research and development. They are also used in the telecommunications, automotive, aerospace, and industrial sectors due to their flexibility, high signal processing speed, and parallel processing abilities.

FPGA configurations are generally written using a hardware description language (HDL) such as VHDL, and logic blocks can be configured to perform complex combinational functions or act as simple logic gates like AND and XOR. They can also include memory elements and can be reprogrammed to implement different logic functions, allowing for flexible reconfigurable computing.

content: Hardware watermarking, also known as IP core watermarking, involves embedding covert marks as design attributes within a hardware or IP core design itself. This can apply to DSP Cores or combinational/sequential circuits, both of which are popular forms of Hardware Watermarking. In DSP Core Watermarking, a secret mark is embedded within the logic elements of the core, typically in the form of a robust signature either in the RTL design or during High Level Synthesis (HLS) design. The process leverages the HLS framework and implants the mark in phases such as scheduling, allocation, and binding. This is done to protect the core

content: High-level synthesis (HLS), also known as C synthesis or ESL synthesis, is an automated design process that takes an abstract behavioral specification of a digital system and creates a register-transfer level structure to realize the behavior. HLS starts with a high-level problem specification and accepts input from languages like ANSI C/C++/SystemC/MATLAB. The code is analyzed, constrained, and transcompiled into a hardware description language (HDL) and then synthesized to the gate level. The goal of HLS is to allow hardware designers to efficiently build and verify hardware by providing better control over design architecture and allowing them to describe the design at a higher level of abstraction. Hardware can be designed at varying levels of abstraction including gate level, RTL, and algorithmic level. While logic synthesis uses an RTL description, HLS works at a higher level and automatically creates cycle-by-cycle detail for hardware implementation. The RTL implementations are then used in a conventional logic synthesis flow to create a gate-level implementation.

subcategories: Silvaco Data Systems v. Intel Corp.

content: A Network on a Chip (NoC) is a communications subsystem typically found on a microchip, allowing modules in a System on a Chip (SoC) to communicate with each other. It is a router-based packet switching network, applying computer networking methods to on-chip communication and offering improvements over traditional bus and crossbar architectures. NoCs come in various topologies, with ongoing experimental research. Proposed in the 2000s as a solution to scalability issues, NoCs route data packets instead of wires, improving scalability and power efficiency in complex SoCs. This emerging technology is expected to grow rapidly with the increasing use of multicore computer architectures.

content: Nvidia NVENC, or Nvidia Encoder, is a feature in Nvidia graphics cards that offloads video encoding from the CPU to a dedicated part of the GPU. It was introduced in March 2012 and is supported in livestreaming and recording programs, as well as video editing apps. Consumer-targeted GeForce graphics cards officially support no more than 3 simultaneously encoding video streams until March 2023, but this restriction can be circumvented on Linux and Windows systems. Professional cards support between 3 and unrestricted simultaneous streams per card, depending on card model and compression quality. Nvidia chips also feature an onboard decoder, NVDEC, to offload video decoding from the CPU.

A sound card, or audio card, is an internal expansion card that allows a computer to input and output audio signals. It can also refer to external audio interfaces used for professional purposes. Some motherboards have integrated sound functionality, and modern video cards can also process sound. Sound cards are used for multimedia applications, video projection, and computer-based communication. They are essential for tasks such as music composition, video and audio editing, presentations, entertainment, voice over

System-on-chip (SoC) is an integrated circuit that combines most or all components of a computer or electronic system, including CPU, memory interfaces, input/output devices, and more on a single microchip. Higher-performance SoCs may include dedicated memory and secondary storage chips, and wireless modems. SoCs may also integrate microcontrollers, microprocessors, and coprocessors with advanced peripherals. Compared to multi-chip architectures, SoCs offer reduced power consumption and smaller size, but have less component replaceability. This trend towards tighter integration is driven by the influence of SoCs and lessons from mobile and embedded computing markets. SoCs are commonly used in mobile and edge computing markets.

content: TLS acceleration, also known as SSL acceleration, offloads processor-intensive public-key encryption for Transport Layer Security to hardware accelerators. This involves a separate card with coprocessors that handle much of the SSL processing, often using custom ASIC

Dynamic Logical Partitioning (DLPAR) allows for the reconfiguration of a logical partition (LPAR) without requiring the shutdown of the operating system running within it. This capability, supported by AIX, IBM i, and Linux on POWER systems, enables the movement of memory, CPU capacity, and I/O interfaces between LPARs within the same server without disruption.

Initially introduced on POWER4 systems, DLPAR has evolved to support additional capabilities such as micro-partitioning on the POWER5 processor, allowing for the configuration of up to 10 LPARs per processor and a maximum of 254 LPARs on a single multiprocessor server.

DLPAR is utilized for various applications, including building agile infrastructures and automating hardware system resource allocation, planning, and provisioning, leading to increased system utilization. For instance, IBM DB2 is able to automatically adjust to changing LPAR resources without requiring a reboot.

In addition to the capabilities on POWER systems, the IBM Z mainframes and their operating systems, including Linux on IBM Z, support more advanced forms of dynamic LPARs such as Intelligent Resource Director, Sysplex, and Hiper
A logical partition (LPAR) is a subset of computer hardware resources, virtualized as a separate computer. A physical machine

Micro-Partitioning is a type of logical partitioning used on IBM systems with POWER5 processors, also known as shared processor partitions. It differs from dedicated processor partitions in how CPU utilization is managed by the POWER Hypervisor (PHYP) firmware. The PHYP controls time slicing, hardware interrupts, resource movement between operating systems, and workload dispatching.

When a shared processor partition is activated, it is guaranteed a certain processing capacity and virtual processors drawn from a pool of shared resources. The minimum processing capacity is 1/10 of a physical processor core, with further granularity of 1/100. The PHYP uses a 10 ms time slicing window for scheduling shared processor partitions. They can be capped or uncapped, with the latter able to exceed the configured processing

Logical Domains (LDoms or LDOM) is a server virtualization and partitioning technology for SPARC V9 processors, initially released by Sun Microsystems in April 2007 and re-branded as Oracle VM Server for SPARC after the Oracle acquisition in January 2010. Each domain is a full virtual machine with a configurable subset of hardware resources, allowing for secure live migration between servers.

A rigid disk block (RDB) is where the Amiga series stores partition and filesystem info on a hard disk. Unlike the PC's master boot record (MBR), the RDB points to a linked list of partition blocks with data such as start, length, filesystem, and boot priority. There's no limit on partition block count, so all partitions are equal. The RDB may also link to additional filesystem drivers for booting from unsupported filesystems. The RDB must start with the ASCII bytes "RDSK" and can be located within the first 16 blocks of a volume. Most Amiga hard disk controllers support the RDB standard, allowing for easy disk exchange between controllers.

Apple Partition Map (APM) is a partition scheme used for 68k and PowerPC Macs, introduced with the Macintosh II. Disks are divided into logical blocks, with 512 bytes per block. The first block contains a data structure called "Driver Descriptor Map" for the Toolbox ROM. APM allows for 32 bits worth of logical blocks, limiting the size of APM disks to 2 TiB. Unlike x86 master boot records, APM maps out all space used and unused on the disk. Some hybrid disks contain both an ISO 9660 primary volume descriptor and an Apple Partition Map, allowing them to work on different types of c

The BIOS boot partition is used by GNU GRUB on legacy BIOS-based computers with GPT-partitioned storage devices to boot an operating system. This layout is known as BIOS/GPT boot. GPT devices require a BIOS boot partition to hold the second stages of GRUB, since the sectors immediately following the first are used to store the partition table. On MBR devices, the space following the first sector is unused, so no extra partition is needed. Boot loaders on MBR devices typically have a first stage in the MBR that loads a more sophisticated se

content: 工程学及其各个子学科中，验收测试是为了确定一个规范或合同的要求是否满足而进行的测试。它可能涉及化学测试、物理测试或性能测试。在系统工程中，可能涉及对系统进行黑盒测试，例如软件、大量制造的机械零件或化学产品批次在交付之前进行的测试。

Analog signature analysis applies a current-limited AC sine wave to troubleshoot electronic components and circuit boards. The resulting waveform is displayed on a signature display, representing the health of the part. By comparing signatures, faulty components can be identified. This technique detects problems on circuit boards by monitorin

Automated optical inspection (AOI) is a non-contact test method used in printed circuit board (PCB) manufacturing to autonomously scan for catastrophic failures and quality defects. It is implemented at various stages of the manufacturing process, including bare board inspection, solder paste inspection (SPI), and pre-reflow and post-reflow stages. AOI systems are commonly used after solder re-flow to inspect for defects like component placement and missing solder. This allows for rew

Automatic test equipment (ATE) is apparatus that automates testing on devices, known as the device under test (DUT), equipment under test (EUT) or unit under test (UUT), to quickly perform measurements and evaluate results. It can range from a simple computer-controlled digital multimeter to a complex system with dozens of test instruments for testing electronic components and systems after fabrication. ATE is also used in avionics, automotive elect

Black-box testing, also known as specification-based testing, is a method that assesses the functionality of software without inspecting its internal workings. It can be used at various testing levels and is also applied in penetration testing, where an ethical hac

Boundary scan is a method for testing interconnects on printed circuit boards or sub-blocks in integrated circuits, and is also used for debugging. The Joint Test Action Group (JTAG) developed the standard for boundary scan testing in 1990, which has since been adopted by electronic device companies worldwide. The standard, known as IEEE Std. 1149.1-1990, also includes the Boundary Scan Descri

Burn-in is a testing process to exercise components before they are placed in service, helping to establish load capacity and detect potential failures. The process involves subjecting the system to stress to identify weak components that could fail early. While burn-in can reduce early failures, it may also shorten product lifetime. It is preferable to eliminate root causes of early failures, rather than relying solely on burn-in. In electronic components, burn-in may involve elevated temperature and voltage, and is sometimes referred to as heat soaking. Some audiophiles also use burn-in to optimize the performance of new audio equipment, although its beneficial effects are debated.

content: A debug port is a diagnostic interface found in electronic systems or integrated circuits for design, development, and debugging, but is not necessary for end-use. In high availability or safety critical systems, it may continue to operate as a system monitor. In low-cost electronics, debug ports may be left enabled to avoid design change costs and can be used by modders an

Design for testing or testability (DFT) involves adding features to a hardware product design to make it easier to develop and apply manufacturing tests, ensuring the product is free of defects. These tests are used at various stages of manufacturing and may also be used for maintenance. They are driven by test programs using automatic test equipment (ATE) or inside the assembled system. In addition to finding defects, tests can provide diagnostic information to locate the source of failure.

DFT is crucial in developing test programs and as an interface for test application and diagnostics. Implementing DFT rules and suggestions makes automatic test pattern generation (ATPG) much easier.

content: The diagnostic design specification outlines how diagnostics will be implemented on new products, detailing test execution, output formatting, and result display. Typically created by the manufacturing team and approved by the software-diagnostic group, it may be delivered in phases due to time constraints. Once agreed upon, it is signed by both teams and subject to document control, with potential for changes as new components are introduced or removed.

Enterprise test software (ETS) is used by manufacturers to standardize product testing across the entire organization, not just in the test engineering department. It integrates and synchronizes test systems with other enterprise functions like R&D,

content: Environmental stress screening (ESS) is the process of subjecting newly manufactured or repaired electronic products to thermal cycling and vibration to reveal latent defects. This helps to identify and eliminate potential failure

content: Fault grading rates testability by comparing detectable defects to total faults. It refines circuitry and patterns iteratively for satisfactory fault coverage.

The final quality audit (FQA) in electronic hardware manufacturing is the last step before shipping a product, ensuring it has passed all manufacturing and testing processes. This includes visual checks and confirming the correct firmware and version have been loaded. Out of the box audit (OBA) may also be done to ensure correct labels and all necessary parts are included. The FQA process also ensures that unit configurations are not altered, and any changes made by the firmware are identified and addressed by the test engineer and firmware developers.

content: Functional testing (FCT) is a critical final quality control test in manufacturing, ensuring product specifications are met. It involves emulating the product's operating environment to identify and correct any functional issues. Automated by production line operators using test software, FCTs rely on communication with external instruments and the test fixture to interface with the device under test (DUT). This ensures that the product functions correctly before it leaves the production line.

A stress test, or torture test, is a thorough and intense testing method used to determine the stability of a system or entity by pushing it beyond normal capacity. It is used to determine breaking points, safe usage limits, and to confirm that specifications are being met. Engineers use stress tests to determine the operating life of an item and to identify modes of failure. The term stress test may have different meanings in specific contexts, such as in materials testing.

Inquisitor is a software suite for hardware diagnostics, stress testing, certification, and benchmarking. It comes in three formats: Standalone, for installing into existing Linux systems with limited tests; Live, as a Linux live CD for thorough testing of a single system; and Enterprise, for advanced testing of multiple systems simultaneously over a network. content: Integration testing, also known as I&T, is a form of software testing where multiple parts of a system are tested together. It contrasts with unit and system level testing. This type of testing is often used to assess a component's compliance with functional requirements. In a structured development process, integration testing takes unit te

JTAG, named after the Joint Test Action Group, is an industry standard for testing printed circuit boards after manufacture. It implements on-chip instrumentation in electronic design automation (EDA) as a complementary tool to digital simulation. JTAG specifies the use of a dedicated debug port with a serial communications interface for low-overhead access, connecting to an on-chip Test Access Port (TAP) and implementing a stateful protocol to access test registers. The Joint Test Action Group was formed in 1985 and the results were codified by the Institute of Electrical and Electronic

content: Level-sensitive scan design (LSSD) is a DFT method in electronics manufacturing tests. It uses separate system and scan clocks to differentiate normal and test mode. Latches are used in pairs, with one having normal data input, output, and clock for system operation. For test mode, the pair forms

Negative-bias temperature instability (NBTI) is a major issue in MOSFETs, causing an increase in threshold voltage and decrease in drain current. It affects both pMOS and nMOS transistors, trapping positive charges at the oxide-semiconductor boundary. The problem is exacerbated as transistors shrink, as there is less averaging of the effect over a large gate area. NBTI becomes more significant in portable electronics, particularly with reduced operating voltages and clock gating, which can disrupt operations and cause rapid accumulation of NBTI effects. Some low-power designs mitigate NBTI effects by switching to a low-frequency clock instead of stopping completely.

Product intelligence refers to automated gathering and analysis of data on the performance of a product in design and manufacturing. This data is then fed back to product managers and engineers to aid in developing the next iteration. The aim is to speed up product innovation, increase competitiveness, and enhance customer sat

System testing, also known as end-to-end (E2E) testing, evaluates a complete software system at the system level. This contrasts with integration or unit testing. It assesses the system's compliance with specified requirements, often from functional or system requirement specifications. System testing can uncover defects in the entire system and verify design, behavior, and customer expectation

A test engineer designs processes for testing products to ensure they meet specifications. They also determine the most effective testing methods to achieve adequate coverage. Additionally, they act as a bridge between manufacturing, design engineer

A testbed is a platform for rigorously testing scientific theories, computing tools, and new technologies. Used across disciplines, they can range from hands-on prototype development in manufacturing to refining intellectual property in software development. Testbeds provide a transparent

White-box testing, also known as clear box testing or glass box testing, focuses on the internal structures and workings of an application rather than its functionality. Testers use an internal perspective of the system to design test cases, choosing inputs to exercise paths through the code and determine expected outputs. This method can be applied at the unit, integration, and system levels of the software testing process, and can uncover errors or problems. However, it has the potential to miss unimplemented parts of the specification or missing requirements. When driven exclusively by agreed specifications, white-box test techniques can help assess unimplemented or missing requirement

The 74181 is a 4-bit slice ALU introduced by Texas Instruments in 1970, the first of its kind on a single chip. It was widely used as the arithmetic/logic core in historical minicomputer CPUs. While no longer in commercial use, it is still referenced in computer organization textbooks and used in college courses for future computer architects. The 74181 marks a

An analog computer uses the continuous variation of physical phenomena to solve problems, while digital computers represent quantities symbolically and by discrete values. They were widely used in scientific and industrial applications and could range from simple tools like slide rules to complex mechanisms for process control. Despite the advent of digital computers, analog computers remained in use for specific applications like aircraft flight simulators and control system teaching in universities. More complex applications, including aircraft flight simulators and synthetic-aperture radar, continued to rely on analog and hybrid computing into the 1980s.

content: A coincidence circuit is an electronic device with one output and multiple inputs that activates only when it receives signals simultaneously. It is widely used in physics and electrical engineering, particularly in particle detectors. Walther Bothe, Nobel Prize winner, discovered the method of coincidence, and Bruno Ros

计算机集群的历史最好由Greg Pfister的《寻找集群》一书中的一个脚注来描述：“DEC在提及集群的每个新闻稿中都会说DEC发明了集群……”IBM也没有发明它们。顾客发明了集群，就是他们无法将所有工作放在一台计算机上，或者需要备份的时候。第一个集群的日期不详，但如果不是在20世纪60年代，甚至是20世纪50年代后期就会很令人惊讶。”

如此人工智能导致的集群计算的约600年工程基础是由IBM的基因·阿姆达尔发明的，他于1967年发表了一篇后来被称为“阿姆达尔定律”的关于并行处理的开创性论文。阿姆达尔定律在数学上描述了人们可以从并行架构中期望的加速度。这篇文章定义了多处理器计算和集群计算的工程基础，其中主要的差异化因素是内部是否支持处理器之间的通信。

因此，早期计算机集群的历史与早期网络的历史或多或少地直接联系在一起，因为发展网络的主要动机之一是将计算资源链接起来，从而创建了实际上的计算机集群。分组交换网络在1962年由兰德公司进行了概念上的发现。利用分组交换网络的概念，ARPANET项目成功创建了世界上第一个基于商品网络的计算机集群，将四个不同的计算机中心相连。ARPANET项目发展成为Internet，可以被看作是“所有计算机集群的母体”，它建立了世界上所有计算机集群的范式，利用分组交换网络进行位置在相互断开的帧中的处理器之间的通信。

从20世纪70年代初开始，客户构建和研究集群的发展与网络和Unix操作系统的发展手牵手进行，因为TCP/IP和施乐PARC项目创建和正式规范了基于网络的通信协议。Hydra操作系统是1971年在卡内基梅隆大学的C.mmp软件集群上建立的。然而直到1983年左右，定义了远程作业分发和文件共享的协议和工具（主要是在BSD Unix的上下文中实现的，由Sun Microsystems实现），因此在商业上变得普遍可用，以及一个共享的文件系统。

第一个商业集群产品是Datapoint在1977年开发的ARCnet。ARCnet并不是一个商业成功，集群并不真正开始起飞，直到Digital Equipment Corporation于1984年为VAX / VMS操作系统推出其VAXcluster产品。ARCnet和VAXcluster产品不仅支持并行计算，还支持共享文件系统和外围设备。其目的是提供并行处理的优势，同时保持数据的可靠性和独特性。VAXcluster，现在是VMScluster，在Alpha，Itanium和x86-64系统上运行的OpenVMS仍然可用。

还有其他两个值得关注的早期商业集群产品，Tandem Himalaya (约1994年的高可用性产品) 和IBM S / 390 Parallel Sysplex (也约于1994年，主要用于商业)。

没有提到1989年Parallel Virtual Machine (PVM)软件的开发。这个基于TCP / IP通信的开源软件实现了虚拟超级计算机的即时创建，即高性能的计算集群，由任何TCP / IP连接的系统组成。这种模型的自由形式异构集群迅速实现了超级计算机的总吞吐量，远远超过最昂贵的“大铁”超级计算机。PVM和廉价的网络PC的出现促使NASA在1993年启动了一个项目，用于构建由商品集群组成的超级计算机。 1995年，Beowulf集群——一个基于商品网络构建的集群，旨在成为能够执行紧密耦合并行HPC计算的“超级计算机”——被发明。这激发了网格计算的独立发展作为一个命名实体，尽管Grid式集群至少与Unix操作系统和Arpanet一样长，无论它是否命名，或者使用它的集群是否命名。

DECtape, originally known as Microtape, is a magnetic tape storage medium used with various Digital Equipment Corporation (DEC) computers, including the PDP-6, PDP-8, LINC-8, PDP-9, PDP-10, PDP-11, PDP-12, and the PDP-15. DEC's 32-bit systems, such as VAX/VMS, offered support for DECtape but it was not officially part of the product lineup.

DDP referred to two environments: IMS DB/DC and CICS/DL/I, each with a Telecommunications Monitor and Database system. Development tools like program validation services were released by IBM to facilitate expansion. The use of "a number of small computers linked to a central computer" allowed for local and central processing, with terminals typically attached locally to a "satellite processor." A floppy disk is a thin, flexible magnetic storage medium encased in a plastic carrier, used with a floppy disk drive (FDD) for reading and writing. It was a popular data format from the 1970s to the 1990s, serving as both primary storage and for data transfers between computers.

Development of the first floppy disk and disk drive began in 1967 at an IBM facility in California, leading to the release of the 8-inch format in 1971. The 5¼-inch format was introduced in 1976, and the 3½-inch format in 1982, eventually replacing the 5¼-inch format.

Floppy disks remained popular for nearly 40 years, but their use declined in the late 1990s with the introduction of high speed computer networking and new formats like USB flash drives. Sony manufactured its last new floppy disks in 2011, marking the near

content: In 1953, IBM invented the hard disk drive, revolutionizing computer data storage. It replaced older, bulkier devices and became widely used in data centers, factories, offices, and homes. Initially 24 inches in diameter, the disk media has been reduced to today's standard sizes of 3.5 and 2.5 inches. The capacity of hard drives has grown significantly, from 5 megabytes in the early days to 22 terabytes in 2023. Unit production peaked in 2010 at about 650 million units and has been declining since then.

term: History of IBM magnetic disk drives
content: IBM manufactured magnetic disk storage devices from 1956 to 2003, when it sold its hard disk drive business to Hitachi. IBM's employees were responsible for many innovations in these products and their technologies. The basic mechanical arrangement of hard disk drives has not changed since the IBM 1301, and drive performance and characteristics are measured by the same standards now as they were in the 1950s. IBM manufactured 8-inch floppy disk drives from 1969 until the mid-1980s, but did not become a significant manufacturer of smaller-sized, 5.25- or 3.5-inch floppy disk drives. By 1996, IBM had stopped making hard disk drives unique to its systems and was offering all its HDDs as an OEM. IBM uses terms such as d

content: The first planar monolithic integrated circuit (IC) chip was demonstrated in 1960. The idea of integrating electronic circuits into a single device started with Werner Jacobi's integrated transistor amplifier in 1949 and Geoffrey Dummer's proposal in 1952. Harwick Johnson filed a prototype IC patent in 1953, followed by similar chip designs proposed by Sidney Darlington and Yasuo Tarui. However, the industry faced challenges until a breakthrough in late 1958 when Jack Kilby of Texas Instruments patented integration principles and created the first prototype ICs. Kurt Lehovec of Sprague Electric Company developed a way to electrically isolate components on a semiconductor crystal. The first monolithic IC chip was invented by Robert Noyce of Fairchild Semiconductor, who connected IC components and proposed insulation improvements using planar process technology. The invention of the IC is disputed, with Kilby ultimately awarded the 2000 Nobel Prize in Physics for his part in its invention. However, historians reinstated the idea of multiple inventors and revised the contribution of Kilby in the 2000s. Modern IC chips are based on Noyce's monolithic IC, rather than Kilby's hybrid IC.

Koomey's law describes a trend in computing hardware where the number of computations per joule of energy doubled every 1.57 years for about 50 years. However, after 2000, this doubling slowed to about once every 2.6 years due to the slowing of Moore's law and the end of Dennard scaling around 2005. This change means a substantial difference in efficiency increase, with a doubling every 1.5 years resulting in a 100-fold increase in efficiency every decade, while a doubling every 2.5 years yields just a 16-fold

Core memory, also known as magnetic-core memory, was a dominant form of computer memory from 1955 to 1975. It uses toroids of hard magnetic material to store information, with each core storing one bit. When an electrical current is applied, the core becomes magnetized, storing a 1 or 0. Reading and writing operations induce electricity into nearby wires, allowing the system to know the value stored in the core. Core memory is non-volatile and can maintain its value even when the power is turned off. It was widely used in mission-critical systems such as the Apollo Guidance Computer. The memory density of core increased over time, reaching about 32 kilobits per cubic foot by the late 1960s. However, the introduction of semiconductor memory chips, especially dynamic random-access memory (DRAM), led to the gradual decline of core memory from the market between 1973 and 1978. Despite its obsolescence, computer memory is still sometimes referred to as "core" by those familiar with the technology. Additionally, the act of saving the entire contents of memory to disk for inspection is still commonly called "core dumps".

Moore's law is the observation that the number of transistors in an integrated circuit doubles every two years. It is named after Gordon Moore, co-founder of Fairchild Semiconductor and Intel, who initially projected a doubling every year in 1965. He revised this forecast to doubling every two years in 1975. Moore's prediction has guided long-term planning in the semiconductor industry and has influenced advancements in digital electronics. However, experts disagree on when Moore's law will cease to apply, with some reporting a slow-down in semiconductor advancement since 2010. In 2022, there is no consensus on whether Moore's law is still applicable.

The processor's clock will increase in regular increments to meet demand, limited by power, current, and thermal limits, as well as the number and frequency of active cores. RivaTuner is a freeware overclocking and hardware monitoring program first developed by Alexey Nicolaychuk in 1997 for Nvidia video cards. It supports Nvidia GPUs from the Riva TNT to the GeForce 700 series and has limited support for the ATI/AMD Radeon series from the Radeon 8500 and above. 

For supported GPUs, RivaTuner is commonly used for overclocking, driver-level Direct3D and OpenGL tweaking, and hardware monitoring. It works with Windows 2000, Windows Server 2003 x32, Windows XP, Windows Vista, Windows 7, Windows 8, Windows 10, and Windows 11, as well as older versions without official support.

Last updated in 2009, RivaTuner has been licensed by computer hardware vendors and integrated into various overclocking utilities, including MSI Afterburner, EVGA Precision X (prior to version 16), and ASUS GPU Tweak. EVGA's termination of its contract with Alexey in 2014 led to community backlash and forced a redesign of its overclocking tool.

AMD Turbo Core, also known as AMD Core Performance Boost (CPB), is a dynamic frequency scaling technology introduced by AMD. It allows the processor to adjust its operating frequency in certain versions of its processors to increase performance when needed, while maintaining lower power and thermal parameters during normal operation. This technology was first implemented with the Phenom II X6 microprocessors and is also available with some AMD A-Series accelerated processing units. AMD Turbo Core is similar to Intel Turbo Bo

Tweaking, also known as trimming, refers to fine-tuning electronic devices through small modifications. This can involve adjusting potentiometers on circuit boards or using specialized tools like a "tweaker." The term was also used for a controversial audio product called Tweek in the 1980s, which claimed to improve e

Cross-platform virtualization allows software to run unmodified on computers with different CPUs and/or operating systems through a combination of dynamic binary translation and operating system call mapping. This saves time and development resources by avoiding recompilation or porting, but it does impose a performance penalty. It can be used as a temporary solution until resources are available to port the software, or to support legacy code on newer and faster machines. Cross-platform virtualization meets the Popek and Goldberg virtualization requirements and is distinct from simple emulation and binary translation. It complements server and desktop virtualization solutions and may employ hardware acceleration techniques to offset translation costs.

A disk image is a snapshot of a storage device's structure and data, typically stored in one or more computer files on another storage device. Originally, disk images were bit-by-bit copies of every sector on a hard disk, often for digital forensic purposes. Now, it is common to only copy allocated data to reduce storage space, using compression and deduplication. Disk imaging is used for digital forensics, cloud computing, system administration, backup strategies, and legacy emulation for digital preservation. content:
Full virtualization is a modern technique developed in the late 1990s that creates instances of a virtual environment, allowing any software capable of executing on raw hardware to run in a virtual machine. It requires a hypervisor, or Super Operating system, to provision and protect virtualized environments, and allows for the allocation of physical computing resources. Full virtualization is not to be confused with IBM Virtual Machine implementations from the 1960s and 1970s.

Other forms of platform virtualization only allow certain or modified software to run within a virtual machine. Full virtualization is only possible with the right combination of hardware and software elements, and was not possible with most of IBM's System/360 series or early System/370 systems. It was also not possible with the x86 platform until the addition of AMD-V and Intel VT-x extensions in 2005-2006. Many platform hypervisors for the x86 platform claimed full virtualization prior to these additions.

A key challenge for full virtualization is the interception and simulation of privileged operations, such as I/O instructions. Full virtualization has been highly successful for sharing a computer system among multiple users, isolating users from each other, and emulating new hardware to achieve improved reliability, security, and productivity.

content: Media Descriptor File (MDF) is a disc image file format used by Alcohol 120% and other programs like Daemon Tools, CDemu, MagicISO, PowerDVD, and WinCDEmu. It can contain multiple layers and optical disc tracks, making it different from ISO images. A Media Descriptor File is a precise, bit-for-bit copy of an optical disc, including file-system metadata. It may also be accompanied by a Media Descriptor Sidecar file (.mds) that contains metadata about the imaged optical disc, including layer breaks and CD/DVD copy protection mechanisms. In addition to supporting Mixed Mode CDs, Alcohol 120%'s MDF/MDS format is one of the few formats to do so, alongside Nero's NRG, BIN/CUE and CloneCD's CCD/IMG/SUB disc image formats.

content: Memory overcommitment involves assigning more memory to virtual computing devices or processes than the physical machine actually has, creating a buffer because virtual machines may not use all the memory they are assigned. This allows for the creation of additional virtual machines. Memory swapping is used to handle spikes in memory usage, but it can lead to performance drops. This concept is not limited to virtualization and is found in most modern operating systems, including the Linux kernel.

AMD's RVI and Intel's EPT implementations support SLAT, while ARM's Stage-2 MMU provides similar functionality for ARMv7ve and ARMv8 architectures.

Thin provisioning in computing uses virtualization to create the illusion of more physical resources. It applies to disk allocation, but can be used for any resource. Thin provisioning is more efficient when the amount of resource used is much smaller than allocated, while thick provisioning is more efficient when resource usage closely matches allocation. Just-in-time allocation and overallocation differ from thin provisioning. Thin provisioning is commonly used in large-scale centralized disk-storage systems, SANs, and storage virtualization systems, allowing space to be easily allocated to servers as needed. It is also known as "sparse volumes" in some contexts.

In computing, CUDA (originally Compute Unified Device Architecture) is a proprietary[1] parallel computing platform and application programming interface (API) that allows software to use certain types of graphics processing units (GPUs) for accelerated general-purpose processing, an approach called general-purpose computing on GPUs (GPGPU). CUDA API and its runtime: The CUDA API is an extension of the C programming language that adds the ability to specify thread-level parallelism in C and also to specify GPU device specific operations (like moving data between the CPU and the GPU). [2] CUDA is a software layer that gives direct access to the GPU's virtual instruction set and parallel computational elements for the execution of compute kernels.[3] In addition to drivers and runtime kernels, the CUDA platform includes compilers, libraries and developer tools to help programmers accelerate their applications.",

GPU virtualization accelerates graphics or GPGPU applications on a virtual machine. It is used in desktop virtualization, cloud gaming, and computational science. content: Appendix H in the Pentium Processor Family Developer's Manual, Volume 3, is infamous for containing documentation only accessible under a legally binding NDA. It described new processor features, including Virtual Mode Extensions (VME) and 4 MB paging. VME improved the virtual 8086 mode by optimizing interrupt handling and reducing traps. The appendix caused frustration among the public, leading to attempts to reverse-engineer the information. Ultimately, the details were moved to the main documentation chapters from the Pentium Pro onwards, making the features publicly accessible.

content: An automatic document feeder (ADF) is a feature in multifunction printers, fax machines, photocopiers, and scanners that allows users to scan, copy, print, or fax multiple-page documents without manually replacing each page. Most fax machines have an ADF, which enables unattended sending of multi-page faxes. Document feeders are described by speed and capacity, with some capable of two-sided scanning. Reversing automatic document feeders (RADFs) scan one side of a page, flip it, and then scan the other side, while duplexing automatic document feeders (DADFs) scan both sides in one pass, offering faster speed for two-sided originals. content: A BAT keyboard is a one-handed chording keyboard with a base and seven keys, allowing for the same functions as a regular keyboard through key combinations. It can be helpful for those with disabilities and as a complement to the mouse, allowing the other

The BBN Butterfly was a massively parallel computer built by Bolt, Beranek and Newman in the 1980s. It had up to 512 CPUs, each with local memory, and a shared memory address space. The first generation used Motorola 68000 processors, followed by a 68010 version, while later models used Motorola 68020 and MC88100 processors. Initially developed as the Voice Funnel, it was later used for the Butterfly Satellite IMP (BSAT) packet switch and the Butterfly Multiprocessor Internet Gateway. It began with a proprietary operating system called Chrysalis, but moved to a Mach kernel operating system in 1989. The largest system with 128 processors was at the University of Rochester Computer Science Department. TotalView, the parallel program debugger developed for the Butterfly, outlived the platform and was ported to other massively parallel machines. No known configurations of the Butterfly appear to be in museums, but at least one system is thought to be within a DARPA autonomous vehicle.

Bus mastering is a feature in many bus architectures that allows a device to initiate direct memory access (DMA) transactions. It is also known as first-party DMA, as opposed to third-party DMA where a system DMA controller handles the transfer.

Modern bus architectures like PCI support multiple devices to bus master, improving performance for general-purpose operating systems. Real-time operating systems may prohibit peripherals from becoming bus masters to maintain deterministic latency.

While bus mastering theoretically allows direct communication between peripheral devices, in practice most peripherals only use it to perform DMA to main memory.

A C2 error, also known as an E32 error, is a read error on a Compact Disc. They can be partially recovered by the hardware error detection and correction scheme, compensating for unreadable data due to scratches or smudges. C2 error correction analyzes multiple frames, improving accuracy compared to C1 error correction, and is also used by the Digital Audio Tape format. content: Cache Only Memory Architecture (COMA) is a memory organization used in multiprocessors where the local memories serve as cache, rather than main memory as in NUMA. In NUMA, each address in the global space has a fixed home node, leading to redundant copies and inefficient memory use. COMA eliminates the home node, allowing data to migrate and reducing redundant copies, but raising issues of data access and memory overflow. Hardware coherence mechanisms are used for migration. Research has explored directory forms, free space maintenance policies, migration policies, and read-only copy policies. Hybrid NUMA-COMA organizations like Reactive NUMA and software-based implementations like ScaleMP have also been proposed.

Cellular architecture allows for running large numbers of concurrent threads within a single processor, achieving speed-up through thread-level parallelism. The Cell processor, containing 9 cores, is used in the PlayStation 3. Another example is Cyclops64, a massively parallel architecture under development by IBM. content: CER model 22, a transistor-based computer, was developed by Mihajlo Pupin Institute in 1967-1968 for banking and data processing applications in Belgrade. Three were purchased by Beobanka, Jugopetrol, and BVK–Belgrade companies. The project teams were led by Dušan Hristović, Svetomir Ojdanić, Veselin Potić, Radivoje Ilić for Beobanka; Dr Sc.
